Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I was counting the last of the bills at my register, my mind focused on making sure every cent matched the receipts. The end-of-shift pressure always made my hands sweat—one mistake, and I’d be stuck here for hours, explaining the shortfall. Just as I was double-checking the totals, I saw Mrs. Patel from down the hall walk into the store. She was the neighbor everyone liked, but today her smile was tight. I remembered the noise complaint that had been circulating on our floor, and the building manager had asked us to be extra courteous in the lobby, to keep things neighborly. Now, here she was, right in front of me, ready to check out. I knew she’d want to talk, maybe clear the air, maybe just be friendly. But I couldn’t afford to lose focus on the register, not with so much money at stake. My heart pounded as I tried to balance the expectation to be a good neighbor—warm, attentive, polite—with the demand to be a precise, efficient cashier. I could feel both roles pulling at me, and I didn’t know which one to answer first.
